definition:
Let $X_1,\ldots,X_n$ be random variables with realizations
$x_i=X_i(\omega)\in\mathbb{R}$, $i=1,\ldots,n$. The *empirical
distribution function* $F_n(x,\omega)$ based on $x_1,\ldots,x_n$ is
$$F_n(x,\omega)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\chi_{A_i}(x,\omega),$$ where
$\chi_{A_i}$ is the indicator function (or characteristic function) and
$A_i=\lbrace(x,\omega)\mid x_i\leq x \rbrace$. Note that each indicator
function is itself a random variable.

The empirical function can be alternatively and equivalently defined by
using the order statistics $X_{(i)}$ of $X_i$ as: $$F_n(x,\omega)= 
\begin{cases}
0 & \text{if $x<x_{(1)}$;}\\
\frac{1}{n} & \text{if $x_{(1)}\leq x<x_{(2)}$, $1\leq k<2$;}\\
\frac{2}{n} & \text{if $x_{(2)}\leq x<x_{(3)}$, $2\leq k<3$;}\\
\vdots\\
\frac{i}{n} & \text{if $x_{(i)}\leq x<x_{(i+1)}$, $i\leq k<i+1$;}\\
\vdots\\
1 & \text{if $x\geq x_{(n)}$;}
\end{cases}$$ where $x_{(i)}$ is the realization of the random variable
$X_{(i)}$ with outcome $\omega$.
